title.narrative: SEC Field Visits to Eth,Uganda and India

description.narrative:
High use of antibiotics in animal production and multi-resistant strains of microbes are a problem in animal farming in both India and the Netherlands. According to a recent scientific review study in the UK this will lead to global crises by 2050, with more deaths than cancer today – the majority in poor regions of Africa and Asia.
In the Netherlands, where numerous initiatives to reduce antibiotic use are being experimented with, with emphasis on law-enforced reduction of antibiotic use by farmers and veterinarians, animal health improvements, and milk quality control. In India age-old techniques with the use of medical plants and other natural products have been developed and – since the early 1990s – revitalized. This process of documentation, assessment, propagation, and popularization of the use of medicinal plants is unique in the world, and provides important insights elsewhere. In 2014 the exchange between experts in the Netherlands and India that combine both experiences has been very successful. This project aimed to reduce the use of antibiotics in dairy production in India and the Netherlands, by increasing the use of medicinal plants and other natural products, combined with integrated animal management and milk quality control. Within both countries the exchange has resulted in numerous new initiatives, strengthened networks, room for the use of medicinal plants and other sustainable practices in dairy farming,and important coverage in the press. In 2015 there will be a follow up of the India - Nl exchange, and a new exchange between Uganda and Ethiopia will be set up. This approval concerns two major exchange activities, one related to the visit to Ethiopia and Uganda in March 2015, and one related to the visit to India in April 2015.

participating-org.narrative: The Center of Expertise Natural Livestock Farming is the Dutch focal point for the collaboration with partners from India, Uganda and Ethiopia on the topic of managing livestock in line with natural processes rather than controlling them. The common goal is to propagate sustainable and natural livestock farming to those interested within the Netherlands and elsewhere. In this way the Centre aims to contribute to food security, environment and quality of life on basis of healthy animals and healthy animal products worldwide.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to social and political participation
